title: "Heat Transfer in a Boiling Pan"
format: pdf
---

## Problem Statement

Water is boiling in an aluminum pan placed on an electrical element on a stovetop. The pan has a bottom that is 0.800 cm thick and 14.0 cm in diameter. The boiling water is evaporating at the rate of 1.00 g/s. What is the temperature difference across (through) the bottom of the pan? Given:

-   Thermal conductivity of aluminum: $k = 220$ W/m·K
-   Latent heat of vaporization (LHV) of water: $L = 2256 \times 10^3 \text{ J/kg}$
-   Thickness of the pan bottom: $s = 0.800 \text{ cm} = 0.00800 \text{ m}$
-   Diameter of the pan bottom: $D = 14.0 \text{ cm} = 0.140 \text{ m}$
-   Mass flow rate of evaporating water: $\dot{m} = 1.00 \text{ g/s} = 0.00100 \text{ kg/s}$

## Solution

### Step 1: Compute the Heat Transfer Rate

The heat energy required to evaporate water is given by: $Q = \dot{m} L$

Substituting values:

$$
Q = (0.00100 \text{ kg/s}) \times (2256 \times 10\^3 \text{ J/kg})
$$ 

$$
Q = 2256 \text{ W}
$$

### Step 2: Compute the Temperature Difference

Heat conduction through the bottom of the pan is given by Fourier’s Law:

$$
Q = k A \frac{\Delta T}{s}
$$

Solving for $\Delta T$:

$$
\Delta T = \frac{Q s}{k A}
$$

The area of the pan bottom is: 
$$
A = \pi \left(\frac{D}{2}\right)^2
$$

$$
A = \pi \left(\frac{0.140}{2}\right)^2
$$

$$
A = \pi (0.0700)^2
$$

$$
A \approx 0.0154 \text{ m}^2
$$

Now, substituting values:

$$
\Delta T = \frac{(2256)(0.00800)}{(220)(0.0154)}
$$

$$
\Delta T \approx \frac{18.048}{3.388}
$$

$$
\Delta T \approx 5.33 \ K
$$

## Final Answer

The temperature difference across the bottom of the pan is approximately:

$$
\mathbf{5.33 \ K}
$$
